awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Thermophotovoltaic system without a vacuum or air gap
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of novel zero gap thermophotovoltaic technology based on fundamental discovery in energy conversion science and material engineering. The innovation provides a feasible pathway, both technologically and economically, to revolutionize the field of waste heat harvesting and management. This new technology will improve the scientific understanding of a broad range of relevant physical effects and potential enhancement mechanisms to further improve energy conversion performance in other waste heat and renewable energy technologies. From the societal and commercial perspective, this project will impact the global trillion-dollar energy and building markets, leading to the improvement in both energy efficiency and substantiality and helping to address the grand challenge of the zero emissions by 2050.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a high performance thermophotovoltaic energy conversion technology (zero gap thermophotovoltaics) that provides thermophotovoltaic renewable power generation to the residential thermal energy market and co-generation to improve the energy efficiency and sustainability of existing residential thermal energy systems. The fundamental mechanism behind the proposed zero gap thermophotovoltaic technology has been validated with proof-of-concept device fabrication and tests.  The unique device structure addresses the existing issues of traditional thermophotovoltaic technology, allowing much higher power output and efficiency, and making it possible for cost-effective, large-scale manufacturing and maintenance-free system level integration. These products, including energy co-generators and heat pump performance augmentation add-on devices, can be integrated easily within existing residential thermal energy systems. They provide a significant competitive advantage to solve the existing challenges faced by the current thermal energy systems manufacturers and integrators: the tradeoffs among energy efficiency, cost, and greenhouse emission reduction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the commercialization potential of a novel renewable energy technology—zero-gap thermophotovoltaics (zTPV). Developed through fundamental research in thermal energy conversion science and materials engineering, this innovation eliminates the traditional air or vacuum gap in thermophotovoltaic systems, achieving high power density and high energy conversion efficiency. Our team has leveraged the NSF I-Corps program to identify potential markets, conduct customer discovery, and refine pathways for bringing this technology to market.

Intellectual Merit

The project advanced the field of renewable energy technology by addressing critical limitations of traditional thermophotovoltaic systems. The unique structure of the zero-gap thermophotovoltaic device offers significant advantages of high power density and efficiency. The innovative design optimizes energy conversion mechanisms, enabling greater power density and performance. Furthermore, the technology's scalability, leveraging the same and mature manufacturing methods as exisiting thermophotovoltaic systems, supports large-scale production and maintenance-free integration into existing systems. This technology has the potential to integrate seamlessly with current thermal energy systems at moderate to high temperatures, enhancing energy efficiency and sustainability.Through the development and testing of proof-of-concept devices, the project also contributed new knowledge in thermophotovoltaics and renewable energy conversion.

Broader Impacts

This project addresses the grand challenges in waste heat management and energy sustainability. Given the fact that approximately 65% of the total annual energy capacity in the US is lost as waste heat, zero-gap TPV technology provides a practical solution for capturing and converting this energy into usable power. By improving energy efficiency and reducing greenhouse gas emissions, this project supports global initiatives for zero emissions by 2050. Furthermore, with applications in both residential and industrial sectors, this innovation has the potential to transform the trillion-dollar energy and building markets.The technology also inspires further research into waste heat harvesting, potentially influencing other renewable energy technologies and materials engineering advancements.

Key Outcomes

The key outcomes of this project are centered around the following aspects: 1) Customer Discovery and Market Validation: our team conducted over 150 customer interviews through the National I-Corps program, regional hubs, and participation in both domestic and international conferences. Through the customer discovery, we have identified key market needs in the residential and industrial thermal energy sectors. 2) Worforce training and leadership development: This project provided interdisciplinary training to team members, enabling them to lead both technical development and entrepreneurial efforts. Students gained hands-on experience in technology development and commercialization. 3) Commercialization Efforts: We have explored potential applications in residential energy co-generation, building thermal energy conversion performance augmentation, and waste heat harvesting for high density, flexible heat and power cogeneration. 4) This project has served a pivotal role in establishing the connection with both domestic and international market of thermal energy conversion systems, advancing the path to commercialization.

Significance and Future Directions

This project demonstrates how fundamental research can drive impactful technological innovation in the field of renewable energy technology. By addressing the trade-offs among cost, efficiency, and sustainability, zTPV technology offers a pathway for revolutionizing energy systems. Future efforts will focus on refining the prototype, exploring broader market opportunities, and advancing commercialization.
